dc:source.dc:abstract: Genetic evaluation is recommended in patients with unexplained dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), but its diagnostic yield and prognostic relevance in unexplained isolated left ventricular dysfunction (LVdys) is unknown.
dc:source.dc:creator: Hazebroek MR
dc:source.dc:title: Prevalence of Pathogenic Gene Mutations and Prognosis Do Not Differ in Isolated Left Ventricular Dysfunction Compared With Dilated Cardiomyopathy.

evidence.dc:description: no DCM but LV dysfunction. This variant is 20x present in 282874 gnomAD alleles and LoF occur relatively frequent in gnomAD

evidence.previousTestingDescription: negative for MYH7, MYBPC3, TNNT2, TNNI3, TPM1, ACTC, MYL2, MYL3, TNNC, G4.5, LDB3 and LMNA

dc:source.dc:abstract: Left ventricular noncompaction (LVNC) causes prominent ventricular trabeculations and reduces cardiac systolic function. The clinical presentation of LVNC ranges from asymptomatic to heart failure. We show that germline mutations in human MIB1 (mindbomb homolog 1), which encodes an E3 ubiquitin ligase that promotes endocytosis of the NOTCH ligands DELTA and JAGGED, cause LVNC in autosomal-dominant pedigrees, with affected individuals showing reduced NOTCH1 activity and reduced expression of target genes. Functional studies in cells and zebrafish embryos and in silico modeling indicate that MIB1 functions as a dimer, which is disrupted by the human mutations. Targeted inactivation of Mib1 in mouse myocardium causes LVNC, a phenotype mimicked by inactivation of myocardial Jagged1 or endocardial Notch1. Myocardial Mib1 mutants show reduced ventricular Notch1 activity, expansion of compact myocardium to proliferative, immature trabeculae and abnormal expression of cardiac development and disease genes. These results implicate NOTCH signaling in LVNC and indicate that MIB1 mutations arrest chamber myocardium development, preventing trabecular maturation and compaction.
dc:source.dc:creator: Luxán G
dc:source.dc:title: Mutations in the NOTCH pathway regulator MIB1 cause left ventricular noncompaction cardiomyopathy.

evidence.dc:description: 13x in 282726 gnomAD alleles and LoF variant occur more in gnomAD than you would expect based on the size of the gene. In family noncompaction cardiomyoathy and LV hypertrophy in some individuals (I:4 en I:7)

dc:source.dc:abstract: The clinical outcomes of noncompaction cardiomyopathy (NCCM) range from asymptomatic to heart failure, arrhythmias, and sudden cardiac death. Genetics play an important role in NCCM.
dc:source.dc:creator: van Waning JI
dc:source.dc:title: Genetics, Clinical Features, and Long-Term Outcome of Noncompaction Cardiomyopathy.

variant show aberration in functional tests zebrafish and HEK293 cells (see page 196-197 and figure 4). Variant is present in gnomAD (45x in 282670  alleles)! and no DCM phenotype =>no points given
gene is expressed in many tissues also heart

dc:source.dc:abstract: Death-associated protein kinase (DAPK) is a multi-domain Ser/Thr protein kinase with an important role in apoptosis regulation. In these studies we have identified a DAPK-interacting protein called DIP-1, which is a novel multi-RING finger protein. The RING finger motifs of DIP-1 have E3 ligase activity that can auto-ubiquitinate DIP-1 in vitro. In vivo, DIP-1 is detected as a polyubiquitinated protein, suggesting that the intracellular levels of DIP-1 are regulated by the ubiquitin-proteasome system. Transient expression of DIP-1 in HeLa cells antagonizes the anti-apoptotic function of DAPK to promote a caspase-dependent apoptosis. These studies also demonstrate that DAPK is an in vitro and in vivo target for ubiquitination by DIP-1, thereby providing a mechanism by which DAPK activities can be regulated through proteasomal degradation.
dc:source.dc:creator: Jin Y
dc:source.dc:title: A death-associated protein kinase (DAPK)-interacting protein, DIP-1, is an E3 ubiquitin ligase that promotes tumor necrosis factor-induced apoptosis and regulates the cellular levels of DAPK.

dc:description:
MIB1 was evaluated for autosomal dominant dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). MIB1 encodes an E3 ubiquitin ligase that promotes endocytosis of the NOTCH ligands DELTA and JAGGED. Notch signaling is a key player in endocardium–myocardium communication. Notch is required for the expression of signaling pathways required for cardiomyocyte proliferation and differentiation during trabeculation (D’Amato et al, 2016, 27260948). In total 8 variants have been published in HGMD professional (As of November 2019) in patients with cardiomyopathy (noncompaction cardiomyopathy, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and isolated left ventricular dysfunction) but without clear signs of dilated cardiomyopathy (Luxan et al, 2013, PMID: 23314057; van Velzen et al, 2017, PMID: 28794111; van Velzen et al, 2018, PMID: 29661763; van Waning et al, 2018, PMID: 29447731; Hazebroek et al, 2018, PMID: 29540472). Seven of them were potential loss of function (LoF) variants (i.e. non-sense, frameshift or potential splice site) and in 4 of them the index patient also carried a second variant (3x LoF in TTN and 1x MYH7 missense) (van Velzen et al, 2017, PMID: 28794111; van Velzen et al, 2018, PMID: 29661763; van Waning et al, 2018, PMID: 29447731). Luxan et al showed co-segregation with the noncompaction phenotype in two families (NM_020774.2(MIB1):c.2827G>T; p.(Val943Phe) and NM_020774.3(MIB1):c.1588C>T; p.(Arg530*), respectively) (2013, PMID: 23314057). Both variants were functionally analyzed in HEK292 cells and zebrafish embryos and showed clear aberrations. However, the missense and the nonsense variant were found 45 and 13 times in about 282000 gnomAD alleles. In addition, LoF variants occur relatively often in gnomAD (more often that you would predict by change) (http://gnomAD.broadinstitute.org). The gnomAD data make the causal relation between variants in MIB1 and cardiomyopathy questionable. So far no disease association with DCM has been published. Therefore, there is no supporting human genetic evidence demonstrating this gene-disease relationship in the literature at this time.  However, this gene-disease association has some supporting experimental expression data and animal model data. The MIB1 mRNA and protein are expressed in the heart (Jin et al, 2002, PMID: 12351649). In the mouse Luxán G et al used in situ hybridization to show that Mib1 is expressed in mouse endocardium and myocardium at embryonic day 9.5 (Luxan et al,2013, PMID: 23314057). Two cardiac specific Mib1 knock-out mouse models both had dilated heart with a thin compact myocardium and large, noncompacted trabeculae protruding toward the ventricular lumen. For the first model Nkx2.5-cre mice were used to knock out the Mib1flox/flox allele. In these mice cre is active in the endocardium and myocardium from E7.5 onward and they died at birth from valve dysfunction. For the second model cTnT-cre (also known as Tnnt2-cre) mice were used. In these mice cre is active from E8.0 onward in the myocardium. In addition, Mib1flox; cTnT-cre mice survive but showed a dilated heart with noncompaction and a significantly reduced ejection fraction (Luxan et al, 2013, PMID: 23314057, Captur et al, 2016, PMID: 27020702).
. No convincing evidence for a casual role for MIB1  and autosomal dominant DCM has been reported. Although this gene-disease assertion is supported by experimental evidence, no reports have directly implicated the gene in humans   This classification was approved by the ClinGen Dilated Cardiomyopathy Working Group on November 8, 2019 (SOP Version 7).
no reported evidence that variants in MIB1 can cause DCM
